awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Direct Assimilation of Low-altitude Magnetic Perturbations in a Global Magnetosphere Model
awd_abstract_narration: An EAGER project to explore newly developed advanced data assimilation methods and implement them in a global magneto-hydro-dynamic (MHD) simulation of the Earth's magnetosphere.  While global MHD magnetospheric models have matured to the point when they can be used for prediction of space weather processes, the fundamental problem that they face is common to all numerical models of any realistic physical system: insufficiently or poorly specified boundary/initial conditions and, possibly, missing physics.  To tackle this problem, the atmospheric weather community has been developing methods of "data assimilation" for the past ~50 years.  In global magnetospheric modeling, the development and implementation of data assimilation methods is hampered by the enormous spatial scales of the system and inevitably poor spatiotemporal coverage of available measurements.  Data assimilation in MHD is particularly challenging because the primary wave modes are non-linear, non-dispersive, and highly anisotropic.  In addition, modern global MHD codes utilize very large grids with up to tens of millions of cells leading to huge covariance matrices that cannot be solved by classical data assimilation approaches.  The project will utilize major new ionospheric observational assets, especially high-cadence magnetometer data from the >70-satellite Iridium constellation.  The low-altitude (~800 km) observations of magnetic perturbations with truly global continuous coverage that are now provided by the NSF AMPERE project, will be used to specify a key inner boundary condition for global MHD models.  In this way, the project will attempt the development of the first-ever data assimilation methodology for global magnetospheric MHD simulations.  If successful, results from this project will lay the ground for transformative advances in global MHD simulations, both as tools of scientific inquiry and for space weather forecasting.

por.por_cntn:
The field of terrestrial weather modeling has used methods of data assimilation for decades. These sofisticated mathematical methods fuse model output and available data in such a way that nudges the models closer to reality as they proceed with their calculations. Until recently data assimilation in space weather modeling was not feasible due to extreme scarsity of data. Space weather describes the near-Earth environment dominated by the terrestrial magnetic field and shielding us from harmful effects of the solar wind -- a flow of ionosized gas emitted by the Sun -- and solar radiation. The spatial domain that space weather models have to span (termed geospace) is enormous: from hundreds to hundreds of thousands of kilometers. Even with the fleet of spacecraft that humanity has sent into geospace during the space age, it is still a handful of point measurements at any given time.
This situation has changed recently with the emergence of distributed datasets measuring key quantities in the ionosphere. Ionosphere is an ionized conducting layer at the top of the atmosphere playing a key role in space weather dynamics. Because of its proximity to the ground, the ionosphere allows global continuous monitoring by spacecraft on low-Earth orbit as well as ground-based facilities such as radars and magnetometers. At the same time, the ionosphere is tightly coupled with the rest of geospace by magnetic field lines permeating the near-Earth environment. In a sense, ionospheric processes display a map of geospace dynamics, and because the ionosphere allows a much more detailed data coverage, the question arises as to whether ionospheric measurements can be assimilated in geospace models.
The major obstacle, however, is that classical methods of data assimilation applied in terrestrial weather modeling are not generally applicable to space weather models. This is both because of differences in the mathematical equations governing geospace and also because of differences in how geospace and atmosphere-ocean systems are driven by external energy sources. Thus a major need appears to develop new methods of data assimilation applicable to space weather models and data sources. 
This project was inspired specifically by an NSF sponsored AMPERE project (http://ampere.jhuapl.edu/) that combines magnetic field measurements from ~80 IridiumTM satellites. An interdisciplinary team of scientists was assembled between the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory and University of California, Los Angeles with expertise in both space weather modeling and data assimilation in terrestrial modeling. As a result of this project, we developed a new method of assimilation of AMPERE-type data in global geospace models. The method has been tested in a "fraternal twins" experiment whereby synthetic data were used instead of real-world measurements. The methods were documented and published in a peer-reviewed publication and thus made available to the larger community. The results of this exploratory project have paved the way for more sophisticated methods of assimilation of real compex data sets and will thus eventually lead to improvements in space weather predictability and mitigation of its potentially harmful impacts.
